title: Who were the men from Spain that came to the New World? What kind of individual were they? Did Spain lose its best warriors when they came to it? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Nothing farther from reality. There were certainly a few well-to-do gentlemen, but they were not the majority. Most of the sailors were either peasants looking for a better living, broken tradesmen running away from their creditors and, in some instances, ex-convicts looking for a place where they wouldn’t be discriminated against. The same applies to the so-called Pilgrims, although some of them were whole families looking to improve their living conditions.

Not at all. Spain’s “best warriors” were fighting (and winning) European wars like the Italian Wars (1494 - 1559.) Sending your best warriors to a remote continent to fight strange peoples who didn’t know about the wheel, gunpowder or steel, not to mention sailing to threaten Spain, would have been totally stupid. Actually, not a few famous Conquistadors weren’t originally warriors. Hernán Cortés, for instance, was a sickly and not-very-brilliant Law student who left for Cuba as a colonist, then became a greedy politician, and used his knowledge of Law to launch his (essentially unauthorized) conquest of Mexico taking advantage of a legal loophole. So you could say that he was a “self-made warrior.” Spain didn’t lose a warrior with him, they gained a “surprise one.” Same with many others. Even if the Crown of Castile would have decided to commit suicide and send large amounts of “top level” warriors to America (thus losing those European wars and possibly being conquered by other Europeans), it would have been a logistical nightmare with the means of that era. In real life, only a few Conquistadores like Francisco Pizarro were actual, respected warriors. Not a few were “the scum of the earth” that nobody really wanted in Spain, or totally irrelevant guys who nobody cared about, chasing wealth and fame that they weren’t able to earn in Europe. Many of them were extremeños, a backwards and very poor region of Castile back then that everybody wanted to flee. Mérida, Medellín, Albu(r)querque, to name a few, are places in Extremadura and the Virgin of Guadalupe is originally from this Guadalupe. The real hardcore Spaniards of the “you-really-don’t-wanna-mess-with-these-guys” kind were in the Tercios Viejos, initially under the command of el Gran Capitán, and they never set foot in America during the Conquista. An elite unit of these Tercios, the Compañías Viejas del Mar de Nápoles (“the old companies of the Neapolitan Sea”), were the first Marines in the world. These Tercios were “Spain’s best warriors” (arguably the best warriors in the world back then) and only a few of them tried their luck in America, after retirement. They were too busy kicking aƨƨes in Europe and the Mediterranean, and protecting Spain itself from their (also very dangerous) neighbors. They weren’t needed in America. So no, Spain didn’t lose any significant number of “best warriors” —at all.
